title: Messaging Guidance
summary: Rulebook for clear, capability-first messaging with practical do/avoid guidance and a quick quality checker.

sections.title: Use this as a pre-publish checklist
sections.body: These rules keep language clear for non-technical decision makers while preserving credibility.

rules.name: Lead with outcomes
do: Describe the operational result first.
Attach one simple metric where possible.
State who benefits inside the business.
avoid: Tool names as the primary headline.

rules.name: Prefer plain language
do: Write for a mixed business and technical audience.
Use short sentences and concrete verbs.
Define uncommon terms once.

rules.name: Name real friction
do: Reference day-to-day execution bottlenecks.
Show how friction appears in team workflows.
Pair pain with a practical next step.

rules.name: Differentiate with specifics
do: Tie each differentiator to a measurable effect.
Explain method, not just promise.
Use clear before-and-after framing.
avoid: Generic claims any firm can make.

rules.name: Back claims with proof
do: Add metrics, artifacts, or concise testimonials.
Specify scope and timeframe for outcomes.
Link proof to one clear claim.
avoid: Proof hidden deep in long pages.

rules.name: Keep voice consistent
do: Use the same core phrases across pages.
Maintain a calm, executive tone.
Align marketing and sales language.

rules.name: Challenge responsibly
do: Contrast approaches without attacking vendors.
Focus on control, speed, and governance.
Frame change as a practical upgrade path.

rules.name: Close with clear next steps
do: Give one primary CTA per section.
Describe what happens after click.
Keep ask proportional to buyer intent.
avoid: Calls to action without business context.

sections.title: Message Checker
suggestions: Replace buzzwords with one concrete outcome.
Break long sentences into one point each.
Use active verbs tied to business action.
Add one piece of evidence for each major claim.
